I've put a do not merge label on this since I'm taking a look at mac and windows failures on the new test. I think that the rest of the source code changes are still ready for a look though, and the problem is in the test or something pre-existing.

I've removed the "do not merge" since I this should be ready for a look again. I updated this PR to also add a `resolve_as_ip_literal` "short circuit" at the top of the c-ares resolution code. This is needed to avoid doing A-record lookups for ipv6 literals and AAAA-record lookups for ipv4 literals. Such lookups are problematic because they add latency and appear to be a source of potential flakiness in tests; originally, the newly enabled tests ran into a couple of timeouts on mac and windows kokoro, and when reproducing these errors, they appear to be due to occasionally not receiving a timely response from the external DNS server.

FYI: the root cause of the test flakes here appears to simply be due to the fact that c-ares bypasses local sys DNS cache daemons. E.g., on linux c-ares bypasses NSS, and on mac and Windows c-ares bypasses the respective local cache daemon. And it seems that the cache daemon plays an especially important role on Mac. When we attempt to resolve an invalid IPv6 address using the c-ares resolver, it will fail to parse it as a valid IPv6 address and proceed to make a DNS lookup to the local name server every time. If, however, we use `getaddrinfo` on mac, then `getaddrinfo` will fail to parse the ipv6 address as an ipv6 literal, look it up with the local name server, but then cache the negative result in the local cache daemon - the behavior can be easily observed by running the `resolver_address_test` on mac with TCP dump. Overall, c-ares on mac seems to end up making a lot more requests to the local name server than the native OS X resolver does, because c-ares bypasses the cache. Thus the high flakiness rate in the newly added test. The only way to go forward with this that I can think of it to just avoid using any targets in tests that might cause c-ares to make a query to the nearby name server, because such a query is inherently flaky (since UDP is in use here).
